ud1.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud1.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud1.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā saṅgāmaji sāvatthiṃ anuppatto hoti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
ud1.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Saṅgāmaji had arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.

ud1.8:1.6.eng: and went to the Jetavana, taking their boy.

ud1.8:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā saṅgāmaji aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisinno hoti.
ud1.8:2.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Saṅgāmaji was sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

ud1.8:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā yenāyasmā saṅgāmaji tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ saṅgāmajiṃ etadavoca:
ud1.8:2.2.eng: Then his former wife went up to him and said,

ud1.8:2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā saṅgāmaji tuṇhī ahosi.
ud1.8:2.4.eng: When she said this, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.

ud1.8:3.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā āyasmantaṃ saṅgāmajiṃ etadavoca:
ud1.8:3.1.eng: For a second time she said,

ud1.8:3.3.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā saṅgāmaji tuṇhī ahosi.
ud1.8:3.3.eng: For a second time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.

ud1.8:4.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā āyasmantaṃ saṅgāmajiṃ etadavoca:
ud1.8:4.1.eng: For a third time she said,

ud1.8:4.3.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā saṅgāmaji tuṇhī ahosi.
ud1.8:4.3.eng: For a third time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.

ud1.8:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā taṃ dārakaṃ āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purato nikkhipitvā pakkāmi:
ud1.8:5.1.eng: Then she put down the boy in front of Saṅgāmaji, saying,

ud1.8:5.2.eng: “This is your child, ascetic. Please raise him.”

ud1.8:6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā saṅgāmaji taṃ dārakaṃ neva olokesi nāpi ālapi.
ud1.8:6.1.eng: But Saṅgāmaji neither looked at the boy nor spoke to him.

ud1.8:6.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikā avidūraṃ gantvā apalokentī addasa āyasmantaṃ saṅgāmajiṃ taṃ dārakaṃ neva olokentaṃ nāpi ālapantaṃ, disvānassā etadahosi:
ud1.8:6.2.eng: Then his former wife went a little distance away. Looking back, she saw Saṅgāmaji ignoring the boy, and thought,

ud1.8:6.3.eng: “This ascetic doesn’t even want his child.”
ud1.8:6.3.comm: Atthiko is tricky to translate due to the vagueness of the base term. Ānandajoti has “need”, while Ṭhānissaro has “care about”. But it is usually used in the sense of “want”, as a synonym of gavesī, etc., or one who desires a kingdom.

ud1.8:6.4.eng: She returned to pick up the boy, then left.

ud1.8:6.5.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena āyasmato saṅgāmajissa purāṇadutiyikāya evarūpaṃ vippakāraṃ.
ud1.8:6.5.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha saw how Saṅgāmaji’s former wife went back for the child.
ud1.8:6.5.comm: For vippakāraṁ, Ānandajoti has “bad manners”, while Ṭhānissaro has “misbehaving”. Neither of these seems justified. PTS dictionary gives only commentarial citations for this word, but it also occurs at Pvr 15:37.7, where it is defined as changes in posture. It seems the Buddha merely observed that the former wife had changed her mind and gone back. Otherwise, the sutta passes no judgment on her behavior.

ud1.8:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.8:7.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.8:8.1.eng: “When she came he was not glad,

ud1.8:8.2.eng: when she left he did not grieve.

ud1.8:8.3.eng: Victorious in battle, freed from chains,

ud1.8:8.4.eng: that’s who I declare a brahmin.”

ud1.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati gayāsīse.
ud1.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on Gayā Head.

ud1.9:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā jaṭilā sītāsu hemantikāsu rattīsu antaraṭṭhake himapātasamaye gayāyaṃ ummujjantipi nimujjantipi, ummujjanimujjampi karonti osiñcantipi, aggimpi juhanti:
ud1.9:1.3.eng: Now at that time—during the cold spell when the snow falls in the January winter—many dreadlocked ascetics plunged in and out of the Gayā river. Plunging and showering, they served the sacred flame, thinking:

ud1.9:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te sambahule jaṭile sītāsu hemantikāsu rattīsu antaraṭṭhake himapātasamaye gayāyaṃ ummujjantepi nimujjantepi ummujjanimujjampi karonte osiñcantepi aggimpi juhante:
ud1.9:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw them plunging in and out.

ud1.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud1.9:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud1.9:4.2.eng: no matter how many people bathe there.

ud1.9:4.3.eng: One who has truth and principle,

ud1.9:4.4.eng: they are pure, they are brahmins.”

ud2.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre mucalindamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud2.1:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the Mucalinda tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud2.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud2.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud2.1:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mahā akālamegho udapādi sattāhavaddalikā sītavātaduddinī.
ud2.1:2.1.eng: Just then a great storm blew up out of season, bringing seven days of precipitation, with cold winds and overcast skies.

ud2.1:2.2.pli: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā sakabhavanā nikkhamitvā bhagavato kāyaṃ sattakkhattuṃ bhogehi parikkhipitvā uparimuddhani mahantaṃ phaṇaṃ vihacca aṭṭhāsi:
ud2.1:2.2.eng: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode, encircled the Buddha’s body with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,

ud2.1:2.3.pli: “mā bhagavantaṃ sītaṃ, mā bhagavantaṃ uṇhaṃ, mā bhagavantaṃ ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphasso”ti.
ud2.1:2.3.eng: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be bothered by flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, or reptiles.”

ud2.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhāsi.
ud2.1:3.1.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.

ud2.1:3.2.pli: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā viddhaṃ vigatavalāhakaṃ devaṃ viditvā bhagavato kāyā bhoge viniveṭhetvā sakavaṇṇaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā māṇavakavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā bhagavato purato aṭṭhāsi pañjaliko bhagavantaṃ namassamāno.
ud2.1:3.2.eng: When he knew the heavens were clear and cloudless, Mucalinda unwrapped his coils from the Buddha’s body. Hiding his own form, he manifested in the form of a brahmin youth. He stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms.

ud2.1:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.1:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.1:5.2.eng: who see the teaching they have learned.

ud2.1:5.3.eng: Kindness for the world is happiness

ud2.1:5.4.eng: for one who’d not harm a living creature.

ud2.1:6.1.eng: Dispassion for the world is happiness

ud2.1:6.2.eng: for one who has gone beyond sensual pleasures.

ud2.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā anupiyāyaṃ viharati ambavane.
ud2.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Anupiya in a mango grove.

ud2.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.10:1.3.eng: Now at that time, Venerable Bhaddiya son of Kāḷīgodhā, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, frequently expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.10:2.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho sambahulā bhikkhū āyasmato bhaddiyassa kāḷīgodhāya puttassa araññagatassapi rukkhamūlagatassapi suññāgāragatassapi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānentassa:

ud2.10:2.4.pli: “nissaṃsayaṃ kho, āvuso, āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto anabhirato brahmacariyaṃ carati,
ud2.10:2.4.eng: “Without a doubt, Venerable Bhaddiya leads the spiritual life dissatisfied.

ud2.10:2.5.pli: yaṃsa pubbe agāriyabhūtassa rajjasukhaṃ, so tamanussaramāno araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.10:2.5.eng: It’s when recalling the pleasures of royalty he formerly enjoyed as a layperson that, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, he frequently expresses this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
ud2.10:3.1.eng: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud2.10:3.2.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:

ud2.10:3.4.pli: Nissaṃsayaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto anabhirato brahmacariyaṃ carati.

ud2.10:3.5.pli: Yaṃsa pubbe agāriyabhūtassa rajjasukhaṃ, so tamanussaramāno araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:

ud2.10:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
ud2.10:4.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

ud2.10:4.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena bhaddiyaṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantehi:
ud2.10:4.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Bhaddiya that

ud2.10:5.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhaddiyaṃ kāḷīgodhāya puttaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.10:5.1.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Bhaddiya and said to him,

ud2.10:5.3.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ bhaddiyaṃ kāḷīgodhāya puttaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
ud2.10:5.3.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Bhaddiya replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

ud2.10:6.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhaddiya, araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.10:6.1.eng: “Is it really true, Bhaddiya, that even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, you frequently express this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.10:7.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, bhaddiya, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:

ud2.10:7.3.pli: “Pubbe me, bhante, agāriyabhūtassa rajjaṃ kārentassa antopi antepure rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi, bahipi antepure rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi, antopi nagare rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi, bahipi nagare rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi, antopi janapade rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi, bahipi janapade rakkhā susaṃvihitā ahosi.
ud2.10:7.3.eng: “Formerly, as a layperson ruling the land, my guard was well organized within and without the royal compound, within and without the city, and within and without the country.

ud2.10:7.4.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, evaṃ rakkhito gopito santo bhīto ubbiggo ussaṅkī utrāsī vihāsiṃ.
ud2.10:7.4.eng: But although I was guarded and defended in this way, I remained fearful, scared, suspicious, and nervous.

ud2.10:7.5.pli: Etarahi kho panāhaṃ, bhante, araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi eko abhīto anubbiggo anussaṅkī anutrāsī appossukko pannalomo paradattavutto, migabhūtena cetasā viharāmi.
ud2.10:7.5.eng: But these days, even when alone in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, I’m not fearful, scared, suspicious, or nervous. I live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, my heart free as a wild deer.

ud2.10:7.6.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno araññagatopi rukkhamūlagatopi suññāgāragatopi abhikkhaṇaṃ udānaṃ udānesiṃ:
ud2.10:7.6.eng: It is for this reason that, even in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty dwelling, I frequently expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.10:8.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.10:8.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.10:9.2.eng: passed beyond any kind of existence;

ud2.10:9.3.eng: happy, free from fear and sorrow—

ud2.10:9.4.eng: even the gods can’t see them.”

ud2.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
ud2.2:1.3.eng: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:

ud2.2:1.4.pli: “ko nu kho, āvuso, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ rājūnaṃ mahaddhanataro vā mahābhogataro vā mahākosataro vā mahāvijitataro vā mahāvāhanataro vā mahabbalataro vā mahiddhikataro vā mahānubhāvataro vā rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro, rājā vā pasenadi kosalo”ti?
ud2.2:1.4.eng: “Which of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?”

ud2.2:1.5.pli: Ayañcarahi tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antarākathā hoti vippakatā.
ud2.2:1.5.eng: At that point the conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.

ud2.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
ud2.2:2.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,

ud2.2:2.3.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā sannipatitā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
ud2.2:2.3.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

ud2.2:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
ud2.2:3.1.eng: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about when the Buddha arrived. The Buddha said,

ud2.2:3.2.pli: ‘ko nu kho, āvuso, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ rājūnaṃ mahaddhanataro vā mahābhogataro vā mahākosataro vā mahāvijitataro vā mahāvāhanataro vā mahabbalataro vā mahiddhikataro vā mahānubhāvataro vā rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro, rājā vā pasenadi kosalo’ti?

ud2.2:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.

ud2.2:4.1.pli: “Na khvetaṃ, bhikkhave, tumhākaṃ patirūpaṃ kulaputtānaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānaṃ yaṃ tumhe evarūpiṃ kathaṃ katheyyātha.
ud2.2:4.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness to talk about such things.

ud2.2:4.2.eng: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:

ud2.2:4.3.pli: dhammī vā kathā ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo”ti.
ud2.2:4.3.eng: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.”

ud2.2:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.2:5.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.2:6.3.eng: is worth even a sixteenth part

ud2.2:6.4.eng: of the happiness of craving’s end.”

ud2.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.3:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā kumārakā antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca jetavanaṃ ahiṃ daṇḍena hananti.
ud2.3:1.3.eng: Now at that time, between Sāvatthī and the Jeta Grove, several boys were hitting a snake with a stick.

ud2.3:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
ud2.3:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud2.3:1.5.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā sambahule kumārake antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca jetavanaṃ ahiṃ daṇḍena hanante.
ud2.3:1.5.eng: He saw the boys hitting the snake.

ud2.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.3:2.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.3:3.2.eng: so if you harm them with a stick

ud2.3:3.3.eng: in search of your own happiness,

ud2.3:3.4.eng: after death you’ll find no happiness.

ud2.3:4.2.eng: so if you don’t harm them with a stick

ud2.3:4.3.eng: in search of your own happiness,

ud2.3:4.4.eng: after death you will find happiness.”

ud2.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito, lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud2.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud2.4:1.4.pli: Bhikkhusaṅghopi sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito, lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud2.4:1.4.eng: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud2.4:1.5.pli: Aññatitthiyā pana paribbājakā asakkatā honti agarukatā amānitā apūjitā anapacitā, na lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud2.4:1.5.eng: But the wanderers who followed other religions were not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they didn’t receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud2.4:1.6.pli: Atha kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato sakkāraṃ asahamānā bhikkhusaṅghassa ca, gāme ca araññe ca bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosenti vihesenti.
ud2.4:1.6.eng: Then those wanderers who followed other religions, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the mendicants in the village and the wilderness.

ud2.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
ud2.4:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

ud2.4:2.2.pli: “etarahi, bhante, bhagavā sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito, lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.

ud2.4:2.3.pli: Bhikkhusaṅghopi sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito, lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.

ud2.4:2.4.pli: Aññatitthiyā pana paribbājakā asakkatā agarukatā amānitā apūjitā anapacitā, na lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.

ud2.4:2.5.pli: Atha kho te, bhante, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato sakkāraṃ asahamānā bhikkhusaṅghassa ca, gāme ca araññe ca bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosenti vihesantī”ti.

ud2.4:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.4:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.4:4.1.eng: “When struck by pleasure and pain <j>in the village or wilderness,

ud2.4:4.2.eng: regard it not as self or alien.
ud2.4:4.2.comm: The suttas vary in how they treat parato (“as alien”). Here one is urged to disidentify from seeing both “as self” and “as alien”, whereas elsewhere seeing things “as alien” is equivalent to seeing them as not-self (Thag 20.1:22.2, MN 74:9.1).

ud2.4:4.4.eng: how would contacts strike one free of attachment?”

ud2.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.5:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro icchānaṅgalako upāsako sāvatthiṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
ud2.5:1.3.eng: Now at that time a certain lay follower from Icchānaṅgalaka arrived at Sāvatthī on some business.

ud2.5:1.4.pli: Atha kho so upāsako sāvatthiyaṃ taṃ karaṇīyaṃ tīretvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud2.5:1.4.eng: Having concluded his business in Sāvatthī he went to see the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

ud2.5:1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ upāsakaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
ud2.5:1.5.eng: The Buddha said this to him:

ud2.5:1.6.pli: “cirassaṃ kho tvaṃ, upāsaka, imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṃ idhāgamanāyā”ti.
ud2.5:1.6.eng: “It’s been a long time, lay follower, since you took the opportunity to come here.”

ud2.5:2.1.pli: “Cirapaṭikāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo, api cāhaṃ kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehi byāvaṭo. Evāhaṃ nāsakkhiṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitun”ti.
ud2.5:2.1.eng: “For a long time I’ve wanted to come and see the Buddha, but I wasn’t able, being prevented by my many duties and responsibilities.”

ud2.5:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.5:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.5:4.1.eng: “One who has nothing is happy indeed,

ud2.5:4.2.eng: a learned person who has appraised the teaching.

ud2.5:4.3.eng: See how troubled are those with attachments,

ud2.5:4.4.eng: a person bound tight to people.”

ud2.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa paribbājakassa daharamāṇavikā pajāpati hoti gabbhinī upavijaññā.
ud2.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time a certain wanderer had a young brahmin wife who was pregnant and about to give birth.

ud2.6:1.4.pli: Atha kho sā paribbājikā taṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:

ud2.6:1.5.pli: “gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, telaṃ āhara, yaṃ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
ud2.6:1.5.eng: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”

ud2.6:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so paribbājako taṃ paribbājikaṃ etadavoca:

ud2.6:2.2.eng: “But where, my dear, can I get oil?”

ud2.6:2.3.pli: Dutiyampi kho sā paribbājikā taṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.6:2.3.eng: For a second time, she said,

ud2.6:2.4.pli: “gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, telaṃ āhara, yaṃ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
ud2.6:2.4.eng: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”

ud2.6:2.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho so paribbājako taṃ paribbājikaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.6:2.5.eng: For a second time, the wanderer said,

ud2.6:2.6.eng: “But where, my dear, can I get oil?”

ud2.6:2.7.pli: Tatiyampi kho sā paribbājikā taṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.6:2.7.eng: For a third time, she said,

ud2.6:2.8.pli: “gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, telaṃ āhara, yaṃ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
ud2.6:2.8.eng: “Go, brahmin, bring oil for my delivery.”

ud2.6:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadatthaṃ pātuṃ dīyati, no nīharituṃ.
ud2.6:3.1.eng: Now at that time ghee and oil were being given away to any ascetic or brahmin at the storehouse of King Pasenadi of Kosala. But it was only to drink there, not to take away.

ud2.6:4.2.pli: “rañño kho pana pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadatthaṃ pātuṃ dīyati, no nīharituṃ.

ud2.6:4.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāraṃ gantvā telassa yāvadatthaṃ pivitvā gharaṃ āgantvā ucchadditvāna dadeyyaṃ, yaṃ imissā vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
ud2.6:4.3.eng: “Why don’t I go to the king’s storehouse, drink as much oil as I can, then come home and throw it up so it can be used for the delivery?”

ud2.6:5.1.pli: Atha kho so paribbājako rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāraṃ gantvā telassa yāvadatthaṃ pivitvā gharaṃ āgantvā neva sakkoti uddhaṃ kātuṃ, na pana adho.
ud2.6:5.1.eng: Then he did just that. But when he got home he was unable to either bring it up or pass it out.

ud2.6:5.2.pli: So dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭho āvaṭṭati parivaṭṭati.
ud2.6:5.2.eng: He rolled to and fro, suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.

ud2.6:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
ud2.6:6.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud2.6:6.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā taṃ paribbājakaṃ dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhaṃ āvaṭṭamānaṃ parivaṭṭamānaṃ.
ud2.6:6.2.eng: He saw the wanderer in agony.

ud2.6:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.6:7.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.6:8.1.eng: “Oh! How happy are those with nothing!

ud2.6:8.2.eng: Hence knowledge masters are people with nothing.

ud2.6:8.3.eng: See how troubled are those with attachments,

ud2.6:8.4.eng: a person bound tight to people.”

ud2.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud2.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud2.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa upāsakassa ekaputtako piyo manāpo kālaṅkato hoti.
ud2.7:1.3.eng: Now at that time a certain lay follower’s dear and beloved only child passed away.

ud2.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā upāsakā allavatthā allakesā divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te upāsake bhagavā etadavoca:
ud2.7:2.1.eng: Then in the middle of the day several lay followers with wet clothes and hair went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

ud2.7:2.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho tumhe, upāsakā, allavatthā allakesā idhūpasaṅkamantā divā divassā”ti?
ud2.7:2.2.eng: “Why, lay followers, have you come here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair?”

ud2.7:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so upāsako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

ud2.7:3.2.pli: “mayhaṃ kho, bhante, ekaputtako piyo manāpo kālaṅkato.
ud2.7:3.2.eng: “Sir, my dear and beloved only child has passed away.

ud2.7:3.3.pli: Tena mayaṃ allavatthā allakesā idhūpasaṅkamantā divā divassā”ti.
ud2.7:3.3.eng: That’s why we came here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair.”

ud2.7:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.7:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.7:5.1.eng: “Hosts of gods and most human beings are bound
ud2.7:5.1.comm: The PTS reading piyarūpāsāta is tempting, and supported by the Udānavarga’s priyarūpasātagrathitā. The commentary reads sukhavedanassādena, which appears to support assāda. But perhaps originally sāta was glossed with sukhavedanā, and assāda was read back into the text by mistake.

ud2.7:5.2.eng: to what seems dear and pleasant.

ud2.7:5.4.eng: they fall under the sway of the King of Death.

ud2.7:6.1.pli: Ye ve divā ca ratto ca,
ud2.7:6.1.eng: The diligent, who day and night

ud2.7:6.3.eng: dig out the root of gloom—

ud2.7:6.4.eng: Death’s bait so hard to escape.”
